posts.post_content:
Strictly better than [Jackal Pup](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jackal Pup), and the art *lets you know* just how insane that Satyr is.  
  
I feel like Wizars was a tad too cautious with his firebreathing effect, though.  
![1](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=1&type=symbol)![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol) *and* one damage for the cost seems like a bit much.  
(![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol) would have been ridiculous of course, it would have been like a red-flavored [Nantuko Shade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nantuko Shade) one drop.)  
  
However, it shouldn't be underestimated:  
As it is, it will hurt you just as much as your opponent. But you don't mind that if it deals more damage, because overall you should be the one delivering more damage in the first turns, which means you'll win if it works out. It can help to twerk out the little needed amount of extra damage to kill a blocker without using another card, or to hurt your opponent a little more. It will definitely have its use in RDW.

posts.post_content: 2/1 or 2/2 for R are almost always strong, unless they sometimes can't attack ([Goblin Cohort](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Goblin Cohort)). Sure, [Foundry Street Denizen](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Foundry Street Denizen) could be a 3/1 on the second turn, and [Legion Loyalist](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Legion Loyalist) has haste and plenty of upside. But Firedrinker Satyr is good on both turn one and turn five, regardless of what you draw or what your opponent has. All those times when you topdecked the 1/1 Denizen or cast Loyalist against a control deck where it is nothing more than a [Raging Goblin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Raging Goblin), the Satyr remains a consistent 2+/1.

posts.post_content:
[Rakdos Cackler](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rakdos Cackler), sure the deck that wants this probably wants them both for maximum 1 drops... But let's compare the two.  
  
They both swing in for two early on and have a mostly irrelevant drawback for an aggro deck. Firedrinker is easier to remove due to the single point of toughness, opponents get bonus value for killing it with burn and so on. You're probably never going to block, but if you ever need to Cackler can come in as a 1/1 to block, this dude can just go straight to smashing face first into an attacker from being played turn 1... With your face. But still, your face will probably hit that creature for 2 (or more) damage. The firedrinker will also make you suffer if you get caught out by a savage surge or a flash creature.  
  
On the bright side, the firedrinker has a mana sink. 1/2 firebreathing isn't amazing, but it's certainly there for you. What that means overall is, Firedrinker Satyr will punish you for misplays more but has more potential for damage t... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
I suppose all the people mentioning Bellows Lizard have really no idea how aggressive cards work, huh? A 2 power 1 drop that gives you a mana sink and can trade up later in the game is really good.   
  
The card doesn't even have a drawback outside monored mirror matches, as if it's gotten to the stage of the game were YOUR life total matters, you have lost already.

posts.post_content:
I would change his pumping to:  
![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol)![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol): Firedrinker Satyr gets +2/+0 until end of turn and deals 2 damage to you. That feels a heck of a lot more rare.  
(I am not a fan of powercreep. This pumping just seems more fair. And it is different in a more exciting way.)  
(There is also still huge potential for this card to hurt you more than it helps you.)

Posted By: EGarrett01 (11/27/2013 10:27:08 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
So, after seeing this Satyr in action (and originally being a detractor) I have to say that he is a house. I originally thought that he would just not be worth it against any midrange or aggro but the truth is that he has little to no drawback against anything but another red deck. Even then, he's still likely dealing the opponent more damage than he's dealing you. My only complaint (as a player, design is well-done) is the lack of a second toughness. Trading this with a leftover mana dork sucks.  
  
Also, I really like the way my opponents play against this guy. They often won't trade [Sylvan Caryatid](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sylvan Caryatid) with it, instead letting me send extra damage to the face. The plays based around his drawback, while they are hard on me, are amazing and remind me of how much I enjoy magic as a game. I once had an opponent exactly lethal me with a [Polukranos, World Eater](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Polukranos, World Eater) activation after I didn't block .
posts.html:
